questions.question: In general how many key elements constitute the entire security structure? Explanation: The 4 key elements that constitute the security are: confidentiality, integrity, authenticity & availability. Authenticity is not considered as one of the key elements in some other secu rity models, but the popular CIA Triad eliminates this as authenticity at times comes under confidentiality & availability.

questions.question: ÔÅ∞Script injection .Similar toSQLinjection, anattacker inserts script language intoaninput fieldinthehopes thatthescripting language willbeexecuted.
questions.explanation: Based on Chapter 4: Data & Application Security course materials.

questions.question: ÔÅ∞Cross -site scripting (XSS) .Anattack where anattacker caninject a malicious script intoHTML content inorder tosteal session cookies andother sensitive information.
questions.explanation: Based on Chapter 4: Data & Application Security course materials.

questions.question: ÔÅ∞Developer training .Software developers should betrained in secure application development techniques.
questions.explanation: Based on Chapter 4: Data & Application Security course materials.

questions.question: ÔÅ∞Developer training .Software developers canbeshown how towrite secure software thatdoes notleave residual code thatcanbeused by other processes.
questions.explanation: Based on Chapter 4: Data & Application Security course materials.

questions.question: ÔÅÆDownloaded software .This includes software ofevery kind from legitimate (and not-so-legitimate) sites.Some ofthissoftware maybe purely benign, butothers canbeTrojan horse programs andworse.
questions.explanation: Based on Chapter 4: Data & Application Security course materials.

questions.question: Layering is also known as defense in depth.

questions.question: Using multiple controls in a series is the concept of layering.

questions.question: Data hiding prevents data from being discovered or accessed by positioning it in a logical storage compartment.

questions.question: Encryption is the art and science of hiding the meaning or intent of a communication.

questions.question: Change management can introduce new vulnerabilities if not properly controlled.

questions.question: The goal of change management is to ensure that any change does not lead to reduced or compromised security.

questions.question: All changes in a secure environment should be reversible.
questions.explanation: Absolute statements are generally false in real-world security.

questions.question: Data classification is the primary means by which data is protected based on its need for secrecy.

questions.question: Securing all data at a high security level is the most cost-effective approach.
questions.explanation: Absolute statements are generally false in real-world security.

questions.question: Top Secret is the highest level of government/military classification.

questions.question: Confidential is the highest level of commercial business classification.

questions.question: Serial security configurations are very narrow but very deep.

questions.question: Parallel security configurations are very wide but very shallow.
